attachments.title: Who’s Fighting Free Speech?
attachments.text: Between the rise of online harassment and alarmist warnings about political correctness, it’s hard to tell who’s speaking and who’s censoring.
attachments.fallback: The New Yorker: Who’s Fighting Free Speech?

text:
Why have a system where you pay for votes? 
Because supporting the community is what gives you privileges. Here’s what you get:
Right to vote on the fee of the Mod and the app 
Ability to influence the public feed
Access to well filtered content (anyone who wants a vote can afford to get one, but spamming is too costly so votes must be selective and are therefore more considered)
Just a thought or two on why this might be helpful for content curation

Filtered content is a value that the user could get for free by refusing to vote, but they know that voting is both what curates the content and funds the whole system. So everyone should feel an obligation to vote for the sake of the community
